WRITING.TEXT:
They added Doomsday, Wonder Woman, and the unnecessary Knightmare stuff. That's what happened lol
Don't forget the jolly rancher.

I have faith in Terrio though.
I'm not sure what happened to BvS's script exactly, but I still trust him.....[Argo is a bloody masterpiece](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WJSH1YNCpWQ)

Just like how you may think my opinion of Snyders supers being the best most modernist comic accurate version of supes on screen as not valid for whatever reason.
I might not agree with your opinion, but I sure as hell won't mock you for it.

You don't even have to flesh out the characters. You can't do that in a 2 and a half hour film that has an invasion plot. Just work on bringing the team together, give them chemistry, moments of levity, and have a plot that makes sense. He does that, and the movie will be liked by general audiences
Yep, JL doesn't have to be an Oscar worthy movie - just a really fun blockbuster movie that doesn't insult the general audience's intelligence.
Good script, good action, good editing and good direction = Great movie.
While the DCEU doesn't have the luxury of solo movies for all it's characters - it can still be amazing if they just focus on each part meticulously.
JL will be the turning point, either it helps the DCEU or it destroys their credibility.

If the guy had gone simpler with BVS, it would have been more successful. He's kind of a "Go all in or go home" type of director
I think he's the type of person that gets excited and wants to put every idea into the movie.
I hope Affleck, Terrio or Johns can guide him so that he focuses on the core characters.

If he leaves out the dream stuff and just focuses on the plot, it SHOULD be at least a modest critical success'
That's what I'm hoping for, Snyder can make a great movie when he focuses on a simple plot.

Uh, Bay is doing something right. The way he shoots action is so iconic they made a name for it. Just because you don't like him doesn't mean he doesn't do anything well
Bay is an extremely competent filmmaker, but the Transformers franchise is utter shit. "The way he shoots" doesn't negate the quality of the end product.
I used Bay as an example to illustrate that while Sandler is a beloved comic.....he has become the ambassador of shitty comedies.
Netflix deciding to host him on their platform has nothing to do with the quality of his movies or him "doing something right", and all to do with his notoriety/B.O draw.....like Bay.
Sandler's brand of comedy has expired, and so has this meme.
Unlike other memes like "For You", "Oscar Winner" and "Zack Attack" which are innocent fun - "Muh Superman" mocks fans of the DCEU who didn't particularly like the way Superman was portrayed in BvS.
I've laughed for a long time, but I feel like this meme encapsulates the way the sub treats criticism.
You can't discuss Superman's character without somebody parroting "Muh Superman" in the comments....and it's become tiring - especially when you're discussing the movie seriously.

I cant take you seriously. You've gotta be kidding me.
I don't see a rebuttal.

WRITING.TITLE: Allison Janney: I Feel Sorry For Sean Spicer - The Late Show with Stephen Colbert

WRITING.TEXT:
You got the appropriate evolution. You just didn't like it.
It wasn't the appropriate evolution.
MoS ended after the BZ event, a time when the panic and fear would be at an all time high. Even at an extremely stressful time, Clark was happy.
Not only was he happy, he was confident enough to destroy the US military's drone.
THAT is Superman.
In BvS, Superman regresses - constantly doubting himself and shutting everyone out.
No one smiles when they're saving other people's lives. Not firefighters, policemen or even Good Samaritans.
Firefighters, Policemen and good samaritans all talk to the people they're saving.
They talk with them, comfort them....and smiling is an extension of that.
I seriously don't get why you can't see that smiling doesn't always denote happiness, it just shows that the person is willing to comfort somebody else in their time of need.
I was in a crash, people helped me out of the car and constantly talked with me and helped alleviate the pain I was feeling - the paramedics also did the same when they arrived.
Imagine if they hadn't said a word? They just pull me out of the car and left....
They're actually focused on doing the saving, not being a hero.
They've already saved the person, they are no longer in danger.
He's not going to be in a jovial mood when people are dying left and right around him. That's not Superman.
People are dying always, do you want Superman to constantly be a sad sack?
I seriously don't get your hatred for a Superman that communicates with people.
He doesn't even have to smile, [just showing concern is enough](https://youtu.be/87ZTS7Fdg90?t=119).
EDIT: [Here is a video illustrating what I'm talking about](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0MTXjsJXUL8). There are thousands of videos like this on the internet, showing police and firefighters talking with the victims and comforting them....even in a situation as absurd as choking on a hotdog.

But this is Snyder. He has a divisive style.
That's not an excuse man.
If WB want an absolute critical success...it can't be in the 50-60 range.
MoS is in that range and it's considered divisive

I consider a critical success like a 60 percent.
It's anything above 80 for me.

[He received a life ban from Egypt](http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/africaandindianocean/egypt/12142149/German-tourist-receives-life-ban-from-Egypt-for-climbing-Giza-pyramid.html), suffice to say they were pretty pissed.

WRITING.TITLE: German tourist climbs the Great Pyramid of Giza

WRITING.TEXT:
I don't think they've read the comics.
Yes, the original trident of Neptune in Roman mythology is three-pronged....but the one in the DC comics is five-pronged.

no because even that "Valid criticism" is a complete and total joke that simple minded people use because they didnt get a jolly go lucky superman who was in the middle of a crisis.
Are you calling me simple minded?
Is it a crime to want a Superman who enjoys his work?
The "Day of the Dead" scene was going in the right direction, but it portrays his heroism in such a morose tone.
I didn't want a "jolly go lucky" Superman, just the appropriate evolution from MoS......a man who is haunted by the BZ event but enjoys his life and loves interacting with people.

Would you personally give Snyder some credit if JL is well received?
Yes, since a director gets the blame when a movie is bad - they should also get the praise if it's good.
However, If both WW and JL are critical successes - I wouldn't ignore the influence of the new management on the DCEU.

Yes, it will change the discussion.
If WW does horribly, **a lot** of people will give up on the DCEU.
If WW is a critical success, people will congratulate Patty Jenkins and discussions regarding the DCEU will slightly change.
If JL is a critical success, the DCEU can consider themselves absolved of all their wrong doings....this is the point where the dialogue truly shifts.
However, if JL is indeed a great movie - everybody but Snyder will be thanked.
Most people would attribute the success of JL to the new management and Geoff Johns holding the reigns.
Why?
Critics didn't like MoS, BvS (and the majority of his movies), if JL is successful - they will attribute the success to the outlier.

While it would be interesting, wouldn't the existence of Doomsday essentially spell the termination of life on Krypton?
Not only can he not be killed, but the kryptonians don't have the same power/abilities as Superman.
I think they should focus on political intrigue and interesting villains like the precursor of Brainiac.
Allusions to Darkseid would be awesome as well.
It's a bummer that Limitless was cancelled.

Which was my immediate thought when I read Every joke has an expiration date
Do you think jokes continue to stay funny, for all eternity?
Hell, even popular trends get old after a short while.
Do you remember planking, YOLO, The Harlem Shake, [Fred](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nEqwKNNQBwc), [Damn Daniel](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PnI-byHtMN0) etc etc

Clearly Netflix doesn't think so.He must be doing something right
That's like saying, "Michael Bay must be doing something right as the director of Transformers - since his movies make bank".
The reality of the matter is, Netflix's decision was purely business driven - using his name and notoriety to get people to watch the abominations he created (The Ridiculous 6, The Do Over, The Cobbler).
The Room is loved universally and celebrated, but you won't hear anybody saying it's a good movie.
So....I don't understand where this convo is going.

Adam Sandler Netflix says otherwise.
Adam Sandler is the **ambassador** of expired jokes.

So what was the best outcome here then? Try to buy someone else's ticket? Obviously it was a mistake to overboard the flight but then what was the right way to correct it?
They could have;
- Increased the compensation and make sure it's in cash, instead of United credit.
- Flown their employees on a different flight.
- Rented a car/bus and drive their employees (Chicago to Louisville is a 5 hour trip).
One thing I do have to clarify, is that the plane **was not overbooked**.
Issues with overbooking are usually resolved just before entering the plane.
The flight was full, there was no overbooking and therefore...United had no right to do what they did.

My initial understanding was that they were getting people onto the plane who were part of the flight crew; not employees flying as passengers.
The employees they wanted to move weren't actually part of **this** flight's crew....but for another flight after they reach Louisville.
Can you point me to anything about this bit specifically because it's the one thing I've been having trouble establishing.
[Here is an article discussing this]( https://www.forbes.com/sites/christinenegroni/2017/04/12/united-flight-not-overbooked-airline-admits/#b9795062f18d)
Normally, an airline overbooks to ensure all of it's seats are filled.
However, the United flight was appropriately filled and there were no issues...until they decided to put their employees on board (a very very late decision if I might add).
Is there anything establishing whether these were people who were required to be on the flight or simply people United wanted on the flight with precedence over this guy?
- United decided to add their own employees on board (who are not apart of *this* crew but were scheduled to fly after reaching Louisville).
- They tried to buy the seats by compensating the passengers with United credit/points.
- Random passengers were told to voluntarily leave the flight.
- David Dao was one of these "randomly chosen passengers".
- He refused - problem starts.

WRITING.TITLE: Lying To Ash Bowden... Big Mistake (Highway Patrol Australia)

Mitchell and Webb: Lifestyle Nutritionists

WRITING.TEXT:
I think there were multiple reasons;
1 - His work as a doctor involved a time sensitive task that he couldn't delay.
2 - It wasn't actually overbooking, United just decided to throw people out because they wanted to get their own crew on the flight. There were many ways to get their crew to their destination (Bus or a flight on a different airline).
3 - The were not giving money as compensation but United credit....which is useless when you don't fly often. What are you going to do with 700 United dollars/points?

I think Anime is at an impasse.
The Japanese movie adaptions of anime/manga lack the funding to create a satisfying enough movie for western fans and the Hollywood adaptions end up disappointing as well (most veering away from the original story's premise anyway).
I think TV adaptions might be the way of the future.
Think of a Netflix show like Marco Polo or SyFy's Expanse.....now imagine adapting anime/manga with the same budget.
Obviously it's a very dangerous gamble, but one that could help revitalise the anime industry.
The reason most movie adaptions fail to deliver is that they try to cram the story of a 12+ episode series in the span of 2-3 hours.
This has always been my dream, but I have always wanted a mecha TV show with a large budget and american writers.
An example of an anime/manga that could really work in this form is [Break Blade](https://myanimelist.net/anime/22433/Break_Blade).
One of the first mecha anime I watched, it's interesting enough to create a captivating story and bland enough to give writers leeway to adapt the story how they want to (without fans getting *that* angry).

[Steins;Gate](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYvhhMjW32k)
[Date A Live](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mmrj39YWrsw)

WRITING.TITLE: The Wizard of Lies: Official Trailer (HBO)

WRITING.TEXT: But if Flash changes the past so that Superman doesn't die....Bruce wouldn't have created the JL....causing a paradox.

So his twin brother that wasn't at his funeral?
The only person from the Daily Planet who went to his funeral in Smallville was Perry, the other reporters wouldn't have a clue.
Therefore, telling Perry the truth and creating the persona of the twin is possible.

But twins. That's cheesy.
That's the point.
It's an extremely bad lie that's covered up by both Perry and Bruce to fix the problem of Superman's death caused.
It's almost a meta joke, Superman is Kal El acting like John to hide the fact that he's Clark Kent......and Superman.
It's the only way his fellow reporters could accept a man that looks **exactly** the same as their dead colleague.
